```python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data from the provided JSON
years = [1438, 1470, 1472, 1474, 1475, 1476, 1477, 1479, 1480, 1483, 1500, 1520, 1525, 1528, 1530, 1536, 1550, 1565, 1583, 1585, 1600, 1764, 1770, 1771, 1784, 1785, 1787, 1788, 1789, 1793, 1799, 1800, 1806, 1811, 1814, 1824, 1827, 1840, 1856, 1862, 1879, 2000]
counts = [1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 2, 13, 12, 3, 4, 3, 1, 1, 1, 2, 7, 1, 2, 1, 1, 4, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 1, 1, 2, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1, 9, 2, 2, 1]

# Create figure and axis
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(16, 6))

# Create bar chart
bars = ax.bar(years, counts, width=8, color='steelblue', edgecolor='navy', alpha=0.7)

# Customize the plot
ax.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax.set_ylabel('Count of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax.set_title('Paintings Count by Year', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)

# Add grid for better readability
ax.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax.set_axisbelow(True)

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
plt.xticks(years, rotation=45, ha='right', fontsize=8)

# Set y-axis to start from 0
ax.set_ylim(bottom=0)

# Add value labels on top of bars for significant counts (>5)
for i, (year, count) in enumerate(zip(years, counts)):
    if count > 5:
        ax.text(year, count + 0.3, str(count), ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

# Tight layout to prevent label cutoff

# Save the plot

plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Plot saved successfully to: {save_path}")

# Close the plot to free memory
plt.close()
